statement: I think the best way to cut down on litter is to hold people personally responsible with real fines that are actually enforced. statement: As someone who spends a lot of time hiking and bird‑watching, seeing trash in parks and on city streets really hits me hard, because it disrespects both our communities and the environment. I think we need stricter fines and better enforcement against littering, but also more public trash and recycling bins, plus community clean‑up programs in low‑income neighborhoods that are too often neglected. Public education campaigns, especially in schools, should highlight how littering affects wildlife and public health, so people actually understand the impact of their actions. Keeping our public spaces clean is an issue of equality and social justice too—everyone, no matter their income or zip code, deserves safe, beautiful places to live and relax.

statement: At 88, I’ve watched the same parks and streams where I bird‑watch gradually collect more plastic and trash, and it breaks my heart and frightens the wildlife I love. We need stronger anti-littering laws that are actually enforced, along with plenty of well-maintained bins and bottle-return programs that make it easy to do the right thing. Just as important, though, is education—especially with young people—about caring for creation and understanding that every wrapper or can tossed on the ground harms God’s creatures and our shared home.
